abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is assessed as
            satisfactory. The transfer of the operation and assets of
            the Rio de Janeiro Subdivision of the Companhia Brasileira
            de Trens Urbanos (CBTU-RJ) to the state of Rio de Janeiro,
            the concession to the private sector, the completion of
            rolling stock and track infrastructure modernization works,
            and the reduction in fare evasion are factors that bolstered
            project sustainability. Both World Bank and Borrower
            performances are rated satisfactory overall. Lessons learned
            pertained to: the need for concession or substantial
            involvement of the private sector in operating and
            maintaining transport systems following the decentralization
            of service delivery; the need for modal integration and
            preventing delays in the delivery of rehabilitated trains,
            and avoiding demand overestimates; the need to address the
            problem of fare evasion as early as possible in project
            implementation to establish the precedents necessary to
            strongly discourage this behavior among regular riders; and
            the need to factor in potential delays in train
            rehabilitation and to avoid quality control problems caused
            by locally manufactured components by resort to tightening
            supervision, bolstering monitoring, and implementing penalties.
